issue.title: [BUG] Fix Prophet with logistic growth #1079

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
#### Reference Issues/PRs
Fixes #1079 and #2444
Copy and paste of #1868 

#### What does this implement/fix? Explain your changes.
Adds the possibility to define the required "cap" and "floor" parameters for Prophet when its growth is set to logistic.

#### Any other comments?
Suggest closing old relevant issues and PRs.

##### For all contributions
- [x] Tests pass locally and [private github-action](https://github.com/k1m190r/sktime/actions/runs/2280446935)
- [x] The PR title starts with [BUG]

body: @fkiraly If you decide that this change should be implemented, I can do this if you would like. I'm relatively new to open source and have never worked as a programmer, I am fairly confident in my ability to do algorithms and to read and write code though. I found the file in the codebase.

well, it's a two- or few-line change, so it would be great if you could make a draft PR and we see if anything breaks - that's also valuable information here. Thanks!

Before merging, I'd still wait a few days for @kejsitake to respond if she find the time to look at this.

But, since it's just a few lines, I see no harm in getting started, under the proviso that it might not get merged in the end.

issue.title: [ENH] Removed interval_width parameter of Prophet

labels.name: bugfix
labels.description: Fixes a known bug or removes unintended behavior

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
Resolves: https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/issues/2626

To restate what is mentioned in the issue, the interval_width parameter of Prophet is not used and is later overwritten, and is not mentioned in the docstring. The initialization logic can be replaced by the default value if needed. So interval_width is removed as an __init__ argument and deleted where self.interval_width = interval_width.

body:
Hi @phershbe and thank you for considering contributing to sktime!

I recall there being something weird about prophet requiring the `interval_width` argument at the time of class initialization, different from the other forecasters that required it only when calling predict_int, but I think that this change shouldn't impact any of that.

> but I think that this change shouldn't impact any of that.

Yes, that's what I also thought, @kejsitake, it should be fine if we feed it some parameter, it doesn't need to be coming from `__init__`.
